 I've read a few different interpretations on Romans 1 written by people trying to justify homosexuality -- several of which even I disagree with. However, one thing seems to be consensus, and this is something I think is fairly clear: Romans 1 is primarily about idolatry and the sinful nature of worshipping artifacts and "gods" other than God, not about homosexuality. When put into context, verses 24-27 show homosexuality to be something of a passing remark in a passage wherein Paul is describing the fate of pagans breaking God's first commandment.
 
 Romans 1:21 "...because, although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became futile in their thoughts, and their foolish hearts were darkened."
 
 Verses 22 and 23 elaborate on this, and then we get to the infamous 24:
 
 "Therefore God also gave them up to uncleanness, in the lusts of their hearts, to dishonor their bodies amongst themselves, ..."
 
 Tacked onto their place right after Romans 1:21-23, Verses 24-27 show "homosexuality" to be a sort of punishment for idolatry -- in other words, Paul is still admonishing the sin of idolatry, not homosexuality.
 
 This admittedly opens up a new can of worms. If homosexuality is a punishment for other sins, it can't be good in the eyes of God, right?
 
 I have a couple responses to that:
 
 First off, I put "homosexuality" in quote marks earlier because there's a large discrepancy between what Paul alludes to in Romans and what homosexuality is considered to be in our society. Well, I can't speak for all of society, but I'm definitely not alone in defining homosexuality to be a relationship built on love, not sexual attraction. Romans discusses the pure act of homosexual sex -- meaningless sex based on lust in this case. If that's all there was to homosexuality, then gay virgins wouldn't exist, since they wouldn't be homosexuals until they actually had sex. Homosexuality is the ability to love and be attracted to someone of the same sex. If a straight man for whatever reason has sex with other men -- even though he's not at all attracted to them nor has the ability to have any sort of meaningful feelings toward them -- he's still straight. 
 
 Secondly -- and this one you might be more inclined to disagree with -- I believe the whole point of the punishment in Romans 1 is to parallel the acts of the pagans. This is the one of the viewpoints I read that I do tend to agree with. God's all about finding a punishment appropriate for the crime, right? In this case, the crime is unnaturally worshipping idols -- remember, they remained pagans "although they knew God". Thus it was going against their very nature to worship some other, false entity, but they did it anyway. So God punishes them by forcing them once again to go against their nature -- by lusting after their own sex. These were arguably straight men, not giving into temptation but suddenly forced to go against their own heterosexuality. This kinda ties in with the first point, about the difference between "homosexuality" in Romans 1 and homosexuality in our society.
 
 As for Leviticus, I don't really have a response to that. I read some interpretation of that passage by some scholar of ancient Hebrew... something about the use of the word 'abomination', I think... but I forgot exactly what it was and I don't remember being that impressed anyway. Like, for example, if a friend my age (mid-twenties) came to me and said they had fallen in love with a teenager, someone ten years younger, and asked if I disapproved. I would have to honestly tell them that I was doubtful that their relationship could ever be healthy and equitable, but I would have to see/know more to be sure. If it seemed that-
 a) the older person involved was very careful of dynamics of power in the relationship
 b) the younger person was very mature and realistic in their view of the older person
 c) the relationship was healthy and functional
 d) they had not been introduced in a way that set up a power dynamic, such as student/teacher, patient/therapist, child/friend of parents', etc.
 e) my friend was aware of any relative danger of being put in jail for the relationship
 - than I don't see how I would have grounds to argue that my friend was doing wrong by that person by being in a relationship with them. The odds of that being the case are slim to none. So, I can sit here and cast about probabilities based on age/gender/difference in age/relative maturity, make a graph, an equation, etc. But suffice to say that it depends on the relationship whether a relationship is healthy, and it depends on the situation whether a person is abusing of another.
